Sampled from a can at the Saint Louis Ratebeer Gathering into tulip glass. Thanks, Dan! Poured a gorgeous deep amber/copper color with some chill haze and nice white foam, lasting with some lace. Aromas of fine malts, caramel and magnificent hops. A uniquely flavorful, refined amber ale. Hops certainly dominate, but it came across as surprisingly balanced nonetheless. Recommended.

Sampled at the St. Louis RB gathering.  It poured a hazy orange amber color with a decent white head. The aroma was of pine hops, grapefruit, and bready caramel malts. The taste added to the aroma, with a mostly bitter finish and some lingering citrus. A very nice IPA.
A wonderful full flavored IPA.  If you can get a bottle of this try it.  I was first turned on to this beer about five years ago and still cant get enough.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2012 For my money, this is hard to beat when its fresh. Piney, citrusy and bitter. Terrific lacing, great ruby color, and the taste stays on your lips for hours afterward. If I lived where I could buy this, Id be hard pressed to drink much else.

Edit: Ugh. I had this again last night, Ive had it probably a half dozen times since my first rate of it and either my palate has changed or this beer has slightly changed.
16 ounce can that poured a ruby grapefruit color with aromas of pine, citrus, and grapefruit.  Flavor is all bitterness with some pine, grapefruit, and pineapple.  Real nice beer.

Can to glass. Aroma of piney and citrus hoppiness. Very attractive on the nose. Pours a ruby color with an excellent white head. The beer has a great pour. The taste is bitter but with a little sweetness that is also there. It seems to be almost perfectly carbonated with a medium body. 

Overall, furious is one of my favorites. As a native minnesotan and beer geek, this beer means a lot to me.

I poured a 16oz can into a tulip glass.

Appearance: One of the darkest IPAs Ive ever seen: pure ruby gem color with massive haze. Forms a small, foamy head which retains and laces fairly well.

Smell: Like a pine forest with tropical fruits growing on the trees. Distinct resin aroma with underlying fruit juice concentrate.

Taste: I did an experiment while tasting Surly Furious for the first time. I had two cans: one was only 11 days old, the other was four months old. I noticed the older can was more in line with a typical West Coast style IPA of grapefruit citrusy bitterness and candy sweetness. The fresh can was more East Coast with rich piney resin bitterness. Its really interesting how just a few months, even in a can, will affect the flavor of the hops.

It begins with a sharp dry bitterness which gives way to malty sweetness. The fresh can is slightly toasty with syrup-like taste for a moment. The older can was like orange juice with distinct tartness and an almost sugary cereal-like sweetness. Both palates end with a sharp hop bite and lingering aftertaste. The fresh can was resiny and cloyingly sweet; the older can was dry acidity. Both palates were very tasty with plenty of qualities I enjoy in a good IPA. I felt that there was a noticeable mildness, almost as if the palate is trying to restrain itself. The can indicates its 99 IBUs, but it doesnt seem quite the high to me. Still, a very satisfying and unique IPA.

Mouthfeel: Slightly thin and tepid (under carbonated?). Hops definitely linger and dry out the tongue.

Drinkability: The well balanced palate combined with the thin mouthfeel make Surly Furious extremely drinkable. Its refreshing while in the mouth, but the hops and sweetness can be a little cloying in the aftertaste. Still, it goes down extremely smooth and lends itself to big gulps rather than sips. A great beer to pair with a meal, but it works perfectly as a beer own its own.

Delicious.Looks like a nice dark pale ale with good sized head.  Great hop forward aroma.  Has a good bitter front, some nice malt in the body and an extremely crisp clean finish.  Shame I cant get it mroe often.

Pretty good stuff.  This is a pine/floral tasting IPA and not very citrusy like most american IPAs.  I enjoy the cascade/centennial/citra IPAs out there but this was an interesting change and very well made.  A bit malty and sweet but it still worked nicely.
This one goes in the pantheum of ipas. Great appearance, strong piney smell, and smooth yet bitter taste. Yum.

16oz can, Needless to say Ive had Furious on many occasion, but decided recently to review.  A complete opposite of my Halloween from last year when I ran a 6 beer gammit that ended with 08 Darkness.  The only thing I had on 10/31, but was fantastic.  Big hops and pine aromas, perfect lacing in the DFH 75 min glass.  Color is a perfect copper, the palate is balanced, the flavor is amazing, biting resin hoppiness.  I wish to god that Surly was available where I was, my god they make great stuff.
Bottle. Amber. Nice hoppy aroma. A little funky. Very hoppy. Not too heavy. Could have a longer finish.

Can from Dennis Brothers. Pours orange/brown with almost no head. A lot of carbonation under the surface. Nice lacing. Aroma has terrific grassy hops. Pine, resin, some earthiness, some of that burnt bacon aroma that is so great ... but grassy hops. Taste brings bitter citrus fruit, pine, a lovely sweet caramel malt back. Finishes very long and bitter, and more bitter. This was one of the beers that taught me to enjoy beer, and I am easily reminded of why.

16 oz can - Floral hops aroma smacks you in the face.  Hazy brown in color.  Obviously a lot of malt to go along with the massive hops.  Tastes quite bitter with a superb hops and malt blend.  Not too much of either, or too much of both, which is just as good.  This is a very interesting beer.  I would have more.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2012 So this was silly, a malt forward floral IPA that rocked. The malt FLAVOR was enhanced without the sweetness. Even tasted a little rye. tons of bitterness, unique take on the style.

Canned 15SEP11

A: Rusty orange with a finger of tan foam which falls quickly to a partial sheet of the same. Excellent clarity. Spotty lace. (4)
S: Resin, grapefruit, sage touches over a slightly sweet malt backbone accentuated with honey notes and the faintest copper fumes. Really nice nose here (4.5)
T: Earthy hops up front, a hint of catty dissonance between the sweeter malts and resiny oils. Doesnt taste as good as it smells, but it is a mighty fine beer. Getting some bubblegum later as it warms. (4)
M: Prickly up front with the body to tame it. Really a great feeling beer with a good oily residue on the finish. (4.5)
O: Really a great beer. Its a month out, and some would call that "stale", but this beer is still lively and quite well constructed. I would imagine some more of the nuances from the hops would be better enumerated in a fresher can, but alas I am not in the distro for this beer. (4.5)

Can provided by FullObs.... Thanks a bunch!... it pours hazy amber with a thick creamy small off white head.... the aroma is fruit, grape, citrus, grape, , mango, caramel.... the flavor is loaded with fruity notes, mango, grape, peach..... very long citric finish..... Great beer !

Can poured into a snifter.  Pours a clear auburn color with off white head.  Lots of pine hop aromas.  Hops apparent at first with sweet carmel malt as a backbone.  My only complaint is the mouthfeel is not as heavy as Id like.

16 fl. oz. can from arminjewell! Pours out hazy, deep golden/amber colour. Off white head with a rocky top and nice clingy foam. Big hoppy nose stands out, piney and resiny. Some sweet caramel malt beneath. Flavour has a malty base with a caramel presence, big hop flavours of spicy pine. Dry finish. Grapefruity and resiny pine aftertaste really coats the throat, and also the tounge. A bit of malt sweetness also is there. Medium bodied, smooth mouthfeel, carbonation works nicely, not too sharp. Nice aggressive flavour profile, hop forward, but still retains excellent drinkability. Would drink this all day.

From can. Pours a deep bronze hue, with a wet tan head.  Has a bright hoppy aroma, with notes of pineapple and grapefruit.  Pretty serious hop flavor, but also quite a lot of warm, bready malt.  Lots of carbonation and very sharp on the tongue.  Either this beer isnt as bitter as I thought it would be, or my tongue has gone numb. Either is possible.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2012 One of the better IPAs Ive had. Surly Furious hits you hard with the aroma of Pine Needles. It feels nice on the palate. Freshly grated orange rind and soft pine needle flavours
This beer is the premier example of a west coast ipa not from the west coast. Insanely drinkable with lots of flavor and character.

Can. Dark reddish amber with a creamy slightly off white head. An amazing combination of malt backbone and hops - very well balanced - nice citrus, light pine, some grapefruit. Nice bitter taste with a hint of sweetness, low carbonation but nice, becomes more bitter and dry with some malt, sweetness and booze coming through towards the end; finish is a complex combination of hops and malt that just keeps on giving, becoming more dry and more bitter (although not necessarily balanced). A great IPA, would love to be able to get this by the case!
I live in Chicago and I might very well drive to Minnesota just to stock up on Furious.  This is hands-down my favorite beer of 2011.

Pint can courtesy of GT2. Pours a brilliantly clear amber with a half inch thick, creamy off-white head that leaves plenty of lacing. Aroma is sharp citrus, and floral hops. body is medium-full. Flavor is very bitter, but with a nice malt backbone that smooths it out allowing the citrusy hops to come through. Very drinkable, wish I had a few more of these!

Ported from BA.

Ive had Furious in just about every possible way, but this is based on my experiences having tank Furious at Darkness Day 2010.

Appearance:
Coppery and orange, a little bit hazier than from the can. Not much head to speak of, but kind of a thin white film sitting on top of the glass.

Smell: Citrusy and very slightly sweet, and an earthiness from the hops. Highly aromatic and well-defined. However its served, you can recognize the smell of a Furious.

Taste:
The citrus strikes again, with an amazing burst of slightly sweet malt. Not as sweet as the smell, but it doesnt need to be. The taste is extremely well balanced, as if this was surgically crafted. The hoppy finish is a beautiful end note.

Mouthfeel:
Fuller than from the can (which has more of a medium body), and nicely crisp. It leaves me feeling like Ive just eaten an apricot.

Drinkability:
Extremely high. The taste leaves you wanting more, and if youre in MN, theres always more to be had.
Have had this many many times.  One of my favorite IPAs.  Deserves the credit it gets!

(16 oz. can via trade with pantanap, thanks Kan!) Pours coppery amber, starts fairly clear but is hazier deeper into can. Two fingers of lightly amber off-white head. Aroma of fresh grapefruit. Mouthfeel smooth, medium-full. Flavor of grapefruit over light caramel and vanilla. Outstanding hop presence.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2016 Ok, this beer rules.  Pours deep copper colour with 2 fingers of eggshell white head that laced the entire way down.  Aroma of hops, grapefruit, hops, mango rinds, hops, pine, and more hops.  Taste of Mango and citron hops balanced by toasted caramel malts and toasted dark bread in the finish.  Perfectly carbonated. A regular purchase when I find it fresh.

Pours a dark amber with tons of head and sticky lacing. Nose is resinous piney notes. First sip is hoppy but malt very present with some toasted flavor the yields to hops. Finish is clean. Best canned beer I ever had.

Canettes de 16 oz. Arômes très intenses de houblons américains à la fois fruités (agrumes, fruits tropicaux) et résineux. Légère présence de malt crystal. Robe cuivrée assez foncée et limpide, effervescence moyenne et peu de mousse. En bouche, les saveurs intenses du houblon sont à lavant-plan, présentant un caractère surtout résineux. On retrouve la présence caramélisée du malt crystal, mais la bière demeure relativement sèche. Finale présentant une très forte amertume. Une IPA très intense et intéressante, mais qui manque peut-être un peu de raffinement.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2013 Date: September 7, 2011 Mode: Can Source: Apple Valley Liquor Appearance: Translucent amber, large head due to aggressive pour, and some lacing. Aroma: Citrus (grapefruit and orange), hops and pine. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, thin to medium bodied, smooth, bitter finish.

Off the tap at Brasa and the MN state fair.  Cloudy golden pour with white head that laced all the way down.  Bold hop flavor, with big pine and grapefruit notes, backed by a great malt build.  Mouthfeel is very substantial.  Reasonable ABV is nice, since youll want to have more than one.  My only regret is not stuffing my suitcase fully of these.  This NEEDS to find its way to TX.
This is quite possibly my greatest weakness in beer. From the resinous piney smell, to the bright red-hue, to the crisp dry finish. There is never a time when I wont drink it.
Incredible.  Smooth and malty with an overwhelming hop aroma.  Subtle bitter finish with notes of pine and citrus.  Really well balanced, not at all overwhelming.  Excellent brew.

16 oz. can. Pours a nice caramel amber. Smells strongly of grapefruit and citrus hop with a hint of sweet malt. Taste comes in asynchronous waves of deep citrus hop bitter and sweet caramel malt -- a nice dynamic balance throughout though. Palate is thick enough to add substance but not too thick to remove the hoppy crispness that the flavor portrays so well. A very nice IPA.

Poured from a can into a glass. Amber in color, nice amount of head with lots of lacing. Piney hop aroma, beer tastes hoppier the more of it I drink. No hint of alcohol in the flavor, great body on this one. Excellent IPA!

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2011 I always love this beer, it has a bit of a red color, and a citric yet piney smell, it is a very well balanced and easy drinking beer. If it was available to me all of the time it would be a staple in my fridge.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2014 A: Rich reddish-amber body... dense, massive off white head comprised of minuscule, tightly packed bubbles... great retention and lacing..

S: I could smell this while pouring at arms length away... delicious pine and grapefruit it what seems perfect balance... slight caramel-toffee malt background

T:  well balanced grapefruit and pine hop bitterness, rich maltiness, perhaps a bit much for my preferences...

M: Smooth, medium bodied, good carbonation, with a crisp finish.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2011 
 Can at home.  August 2011. Big thanks to Steve (fbm115) for sending this amazing beer.

Pours golden amber, glitteringly clear with a frothy eggshell-white head. When sinking my nose towards the glass Im about to go crazy, its that fantastic. The fresh aroma of hop cones is preserved and I get the most wonderful fragrances of pineapple, grapefruit, citruses, resin, pine and grass. Super clean and crisp. I also appreciate that theres no real sweetness to it, its very subtile. This makes it come together a lot better and showcases the hops in a superior way.


The big hop character is reappearing  in the taste and everything else rotates around that. The balance between sweetness and bitterness is spot on, neither is dominating. With such a rich hop aroma this is surprising, many other IPAs and IIPAs have a problem with being to sweet and sticky in the taste. Not Furious. The malt flavour is present in the taste and adds another facet to the beer. What more can I say, I wish the can was larger? When an IPA appear like a Double IPA in terms of taste and aroma you can be damn sure its good. Thanks again Steve for sending me the best IPA I had this summer.

Pours an amber ruby color with a medium tan head...nice lacing and retention.  Aroma is earthy and spicy...subtle citrus...light roasty malt backing.  Flavor follows suit...great hop profile...subtle citrus sets off the earthy/spicy noted perfectly and good malt backing!  Mouthfeel is silky and the finish lingers nicely with spiced grapefruit...dry.  damn good!
UPDATED: AUG 24, 2011 Poured a copper color.  Lite head.  Aroma of maltiness and floral hops.  Med bitterness.  Oily texture, med body.  Bitter finish.  Good hoppy bear with a blanced malt backbone.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2011 Poured from a tap into a pint at Kings Wine Bar in Minneapolis, Minn. Color was a mix of copper and orange. Missed the head, but the lacing was high and consistent throughout the beer. 

Lots of different strong flavors that blended well together. Kind of like the Abrasive that I had earlier in the day, it was a good mixture of dark (chocolate, caramel, malty) and citrus (pine, grapefruit). 

The taste was similar to the smell, down to the mixes. The lacing stayed on my unshaven face, which I enjoyed. Slight bitterness, but all the blended flavors kind of outweigh it.

Average carbonation. So good throughout, just smooth and consistent. 

I wish I would have had this before the Abrasive. The ratings would have been higher. Still loved the Furious.

Big tannish head, light ruby amber color, clear, good retention, good lacing, looks everything youd like it to..  aroma, loads of citrus, some pine and some mild sweetness... super dry finish, medium bodied to medium thin bodied for an ipa, lively, loads of evergreen but not in an overpowering or offensive way, some citrus, no real sweetness in the flavor, worthy worthy worthy...

Poured from a can.  Copper with an off white head. Pine and slight muddled citrus on the nose.  Flavor starts with pine, hop resin, solid malt backbone and a nice bitter finish.  The bitterness is very well done.  Perfect body and carbonation for an American IPA.  This would be perfect with more citrus in the flavor and aroma.  Very good IPA.  Thank you bobbypaulson for sending this!

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2011 Thanks to whoever brought this one to our IPA day party.

A - Pours golden amber orange with a nice one finger tall white head leaving spotty lacing down the glass.

S - Smells of tropical fruits; like grapefruit and mango; pungent citric hops, and some light sweetness, possibly from the caramel malt.

T - Starts off with a big dose of bitter citric hops slowly giving way to a mix of tropical fruits; like mango, grapefruit, and orange peel; sweet caramel malt, and a touch of chewiness toward the very end. The finish is a mix of juicy fruit, hop bitterness, and a touch of dryness, lingering for a short period of time.

M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Bitter-Sweet feel with a good bit of it lingering through the finish. A tiny bit too sweet but overall it has very good balance.

O - Pretty damn good. When fresh, this one is really hard to beat. I still prefer Abrasive over this one but either one would be great in my book. I look forward to my next encounter with the awesomeness that is Furious.

Can (trade with Skyview).  Sweet orange/tangerine and pine hops aroma.  Clear amber color with large head.  MIldly sweet orange, barley malt and moderately bitter pine and grapefruit peel hops flavor.  Very nice.

Figured it was about time to rate this after countless trades for cans over the last year.  Thanks for this one Mark!  Pours an amber/copper color with a white head that has nice lacing.  The aroma just says Surly.  Who knows if that is something I can really pick up or if it is just the can.  Tons of grapefruit citrus hops in the nose. Love this smell.  The taste is one of the best IPAs Ive had.  Again, I really think the can makes a difference with retention of hop profile.  Citrus, pine, all the good stuff.  Overall, this could be my favorite single IPA.  Minnesota is a lucky state to have this beer readily available.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Pours an orange/amber body with a white bubbly head that leaves behind plenty of lacing.  It smells of piney hops with a bit of a resinous smell as well.  Medium sweetness, that is moderatley bitter.  sticky, medium body, average carbonation.
UPDATED: OCT 16, 2011 Tried this on tap in Minneapolis. Very good hoppy beer. A great Minnesota micro-brew.

RBSG 2010 - bus to Ypsilanti I think. Orangy colour, solid cap. Hopfest! Simcoe, pine, orange, grapefruit, floral, light herbal, caramel and candy, tropical things and more and more pine - everything a growing IPA addict requires. The flavour is pretty good but nothing out of the ordinary. Grapefruit grapefruit, pine and resin, lemon, sweet caramel, some spice. Faily well balanced and smooth. The aftertaste almost hurts. Good times! Gonna be drunk before we get to the festival.

16oz canned June 9, 2011.  Served at around 45F.  Big thanks to Ryan for this one!

Pours lightly hazy red/copper with a two finger off white head that leaves some impressive rings of lacing and recedes to a light cap.  One of the darkest IPAs Ive seen.

Aroma is heavy on the pine and grapefruit rind citrus notes, a bit dank, some caramel and bready malt but the hops take center stage.  Very good strength.

Flavor starts with intense grapefruit citrus, a good dose of pine, some resinous hops, moderate bready malt backbone but doesnt do much to deter the finishing wave of strong bitterness.  

Mouthfeel is medium bodied with very good carbonation.

Damn.  Intense stuff!  Grapefruit and pine bomb, very straightforward but they nailed it.  A treat, for sure!

Tallboy can courtesy of the wonderful, wonderful internet.  Pours a hazy dark copper with a medium-lived white head.  Aroma is powerful piney hop resin with a fair bit of lemon and caramel.  Flavors match, with a healthy backbone of the Scottish malt, which is actually pleasant, but with a finish thats overly sharp and dry for my taste, but to be expected for 100 IBUs.

Can thanks to a very generous trader. Pours dark amber brown. Off white head. Nose of intense hops, caramel malt. pine, resin and grapefruit. Taste is strong grapefruit, hops, pine, resin and a full caramel malt body. Well balanced. Grapefruit rind bitter finish.

Big IPA with mounds of hops. A hops lovers dream especially if you like stanky, sticky herbal hops. I was impressed. The fact that its made exclusively in a can is even better. Wish there were 100 more beers like this one. My only criticism is that I wish the beer had some more malt backbone. Not enough to be imperial or anything, but this is hops and more hops. Thats it.

Poured from a can thanks to Tyler in a recent trade. Nice rich amber color with a moderate off white head. Aromas of malt and a bit of grassy hops. Medium in body and smooth. Solid malt presence with a slight sweetness. Hops are present right up there and finish is pretty balanced leaning on the drier side. Pretty good beer.

Can shared by jtclockwork (thanks!) as a leftover gimme from the RBSG grandtasting. Unfortunately, I discovered it had been crushed open during my bus ride home from RBSG, so I had to drink the half a can that was left that night. Pours a murky and hazy burnt orange. Rich aroma of caramel, perfume, passionfruit, orange peel, and pine. Flavor has plenty of hop punch and malty stickiness. Orange peel, pine, perfume, toffee, coconut. Slightly boozy. Hop punch dissipates more quickly than Id like, but some nice malt stickiness remains. An excellent IPA.

Sampled from can with my good friend raveskdr.I normally dont buy into the hype, but man the moment this one was poured, it was freaking awesome. Poured an orange color with a medium-small white head. Aroma was grapefruit, pine, hoppy hoppy hoppy. Bitter, pine. It was so wonderful. Alcohol is about perfect, at only 6.2%.

Can poured into a pint glass.  This beer pours amber with a light tan head that is long lasting and creamy.  The beer has aromas of bitter citrus, like grapefruit.  Taste is equally as great with notes of bitter hops leaving a very citrusy taste with well balanced pine flavor, and a finish that is clean and crisp.  Palate is medium, creamy, and average carbonation.  Overall, this is one fantastic brew that I wish I could regularly buy.  Very flavorful without being too sweet, too bitter, or to heavy.  Nicely done.

Can from bhensonb. Pours orange copper with a thick apricot head and a toffee aroma. There is a rich caramel malt flavor that sticks to the palate and very interesting hop profile that provides sufficient bitterness without a puckering reaction. This beer is quite well-balanced and packs a lot of flavor for a 6.2 ABV.

From a can. My first Surly beer. Lovely, hopheads dream aroma, pine and grapefruit and some grass, maybe a little nutty. Super bitter, a little lemony sour, thin but smooth, if that makes any sense. Really great lacing, and a very attractive, richly colored beer. I havent smelled a beer this piney in a while. First impression is its in the Two Hearted/Stone IPA classification. It may be a little bit too bitter. Ive been thinking, I dont rate many beers poorly. But I also make a point of trying not to drink beers that arent going to be any good.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2011 Tap in a pint glass at Surly Brewery.  This was the second time I had tried this beer. The first time, I remember how hoppy it tasted.  This time, I tried it after drinking Surlys Smoke Lager and the first thing I noticed from the Furious was grapefruit, instead of the hoppiness!  Another interesting a complex beer from Surly.
Can from TheAlum.  Nice mix of hop presence in the nose.  Smooth hop bitterness with a decent malt backbone.  Overall, a very good IPA.  Nothing outlandish.

A: This is a bit darker for an IPA has a red hue and some good carbonation

S: Massive hops and that is all I can really detect from this beer.

T: Taste is strong and bitter, delicious! If I were tasting this blind I would think it was a DIPA. Very refreshing and crisp. The low(er) ABV makes this a perfect summer brew.

M: Thin and smooth with a nice prickly carbonation.

O: I think this is a great beer from a great brewery!

Can, thanks to GT2 for spotting it.  Two fingers of light tan foamy head that leaves rings of lacing; ambery red-brown color thats very murky.  Loving the aroma on this: loads of grapefruity hoppiness, resin, earth, and very pungent and juicy hops.  The flavor is not nearly as vibrant as the aroma, though its still pretty solid.  Not quite as aggressive as the aroma, but definitely still quite bitter with fresh grapefruit rind, touch of resin, and a good deal of maltiness that stay fairly well in check but gives a lot of body and balance.  Not as dry as others, but pretty damn good.  Aroma really did it for me.  Medium body with softer carbonation.

"this is true", thats all i could think when i finally got a chance to try this one, been waiting awhile. sometimes, more so than i would like, things dont add up to the hype surrounding them, maybe sometimes its a fad, or plain doesnt live up to the excitement, but this was really good, and i was happy because of it. good hoppy ipa for those of us hopheads.
Super hoppy red ale that has a big aroma and serious malt taste. Sweet, hoppy, caramel and refreshing too. Very clean, very awesome. Why cant I get this all the time

More like an amazing hoppy amber than an IPA, piney hops on the nose and hints of sweet caramel backing.  Manages to effortlessly blend good amber malt flavors with intense but restrained mouth drying hops. Consistently excellent; the sort of beer that we all deserve to drink regularly.

16 oz can courtesy of Jeff...thanks!  Pours a reddish brown with decent head.  Smells of pine but some background sweetness.  Really balanced throughout.  Surprisingly malty, but you certainly cant miss the hops.  This is a sensational beer, easily one of the best Ive ever had.

Pours opaque brownish red with a fair amount of sed. Smells of citrus, grapefruit, caramel malts, and a sweet almost honey note. This beer is very interesing the sweet malts start big and then half way through the swallow it thins to a light sweet grainy taste and as it progresses I get some pine and grapefruit. Mouthfeel is pleasant and light and finish is long and bitter but a clean finish.

Pours a murky brown with a full white head and leaves a white halo around the beer.  Smells of rich heavy citrus hops, crystal malt, pine and honey.  The hops are nicely presented with a slight bitterness, sweet caramels, toffee, and honey all upfront.  The flavor thins out and then comes on strong again near the finish turns to a nice grainy aspect.  The bitterness lingers for a decent amount of time.

pours a clear amber with a white head. aroma is very piny with grapefruit, and citrus. flavor was also very piney and malty. very sweet. pretty smooth drinker. i like it but i was drinking an ipa that was 7 weeks old. ill try to get it fresher next time. still pretty damn good though!

Big woodsy hop aroma on this red colored ale to with a touch of the cat pee smell at the back.  Big and resiny.  Doesnt scrape the palate but leaves it mark on the tongue.  Slightly warming too. A couple other flavors that I cant name are swirling in there too.

Cant help but like killer IPA that comes from a can.  Pours amber and bubbly, with a nose of grapefruit and lemon zest that powers down your sinus cavity.  Sweet yet oh so hoppy, the nose on this IPA is brilliant.  The citrus-juiced hops follow through into the flavor, yet theres a danish-like malt center that give startling balance to this 100 IBU behemoth.  A single IPA this big that is this easy to put back makes for quite the achievement.  (3/2/09)
Very hoppy, malty and bitter in taste, a true contrast to the Bender. I get why people enjoy the Furious, but this ale is not for me.

A - Pours a clear copper red color with a big finger of frothy off-white head. The head fades slowly down to a thick ring around the glass leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is full of piney and floral hops. There is also some fruity esters, some malt beneath, and a bit of citrus as well.

T - Starts out with some strong hops flavor and lots of grapefruit. There is some sweet malt in the background to provide some balance. Through the middle some strong bitterness and floral flavors come through. But of light fruit in the mix. The finish is a mix of hops bitterness and some background malts and grapefruit that linger nicely.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Really smooth and crisp. The lingering bitterness is fairly strong and leaves a nice dry mouthfeel.

D - Very drinkable. Very nice and powerful hop profile. There is also enough malt and fruit flavor to balance out the flavors.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2014 The perfect IPA, great appearance, great taste, great beer. The hints of pine hops and citrus hit you at different levels with each sip creating a great overall experience. Surly is doing something very right, if you have the chance, try this beer!

Poured from 16oz can into a tasting glass, pours a clear amber with a white head, aroma is full of citrus with pine, the flavor is very smooth and has a great mixture of tropical fruit with the malt, very balanced ipa, wish I had this one in Wisconsin.

On tap at Crave. Pours cloudy deep caramel.milky tan head with great head retention and lacing. Pine, grapefruit, caramel malts.not too spicy,some resin. Really tasty! Pine, malts, quick bitter bomb that fades quickly. Really balanced. Medium finish. What a pleasant surprise find.
Pours reddish copper with small head. Pine and citrus on the nose.  Lots of bitter citrus with a medium body and pleasant finish.  Nice beer, I wish it was available locally.

Aww yeah!!! Another great can from Tyloanderso. Ruddy hued beauty with a creamy thick head. Hoppy delight of an aroma belies the wonderful balance of malt and hop in the flavor, on top of a great long pleasingly bitter finish.

12 oz. bottle from Minnesotans fridge

Ar:  Hoptastic aroma.  Crap ton of citrus, some pine.  Touch of caramel.
Ap:  Pours a deep hazy copper with a pillowy 1 1/2" head atop my tulip.  Excellent head retention.  Great lace.
T:  Citrus rind and resin from the hops.  Moderately sweet with caramel notes, but dominated by hoppage (not that Im complaining).  Packs the bitterness wallop of a IIPA.
P:  Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation.  Very clean palate.

O:  Excellent IPA.  Definitely the most thoroughly hopped standard IPA Ive ever had, and this was damn enjoyable for 16 oz.
Amber pour with off-white head. Aroma is citrus and pine. The flavor is the same with some caramel malts. Nothing overly impressing but definitely good.

Can courtesy of mtjoseph, thanks Mark.  Massive hop bouquet comes bursting out of the can; loads of citrus aroma, spiciness, a bit of pine, but dominated by grapefruit, slight solvent note.  Pours a deep copper with a slight haze, thick billowing off-white head with great retention and lots of lacing.  Flavor is definitely balanced towards the hops, with citrus and pine flavors in spades.  Good malt character, caramel, toasty, fresh grains.  High bitterness up front, with a fairly long, bitter finish.  Medium body and medium-high carbonation.  Great APA, wish I had regular access to it.

It pours a very dark copper with a half finger white head that stays awhile with excellent lacing. 

The aroma is very hoppy with very subtle notes of orange and spice.

The tatse is hoppy throughout and not very complex. It is not the typical IPA start and finish. Its kinda sweet throughout but hops dominates. 

Mouthfeel is decent and you can slam this.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2013 16 oz can from the Todd selection...thanks!!! Pop the top and you smell the hoppiness right away....not a sharp, astringent nose...just sweet hops without the sting! The taste matches the nose....hoppy but not hot...the malts mellow things out and make for a very mellow, hoppy IPA....wish I had more...
Edits....10/16/13...update from DRAFT at MSP airport....still wonderful but actually a tad better on draft...hoppy edge but still mellow....wish to hell they had this more often in Chi-town.
On tap @ Muddy Pig. Red orange appearance with an off white head. Big piney, grapefruity nose. Sweet grapefruity, earthy, piney hoppy flavor. Grapefruity finish.

From the can and there were only four of them and next time it will be 44.  I was skeptical about a tall can of IPA.  Ill build a froth of the aromas and flavors and go beyond.  I dunno.  Its good IPA.
UPDATED: JUN 2, 2011 Poured a nice golden color with minimal head. Has a very pungent hop scent, and the taste is very bitter.

Cloudy bronze, big frothy head and a piny resinous aroma. A grassy, pine and grapefruit taste with a a great balance of maltiness followed by a bitter finish. Due to all the hype Id heard about this beer, I had EXTREMELY high standards, and to be honest it fell a little short. Despite that, its a fucking awesome IPA.

(beer tasting @ Montys Krown - Rochester, NY: can - 500 ml) Copper color with a thin white head. Heavy and peppery hop aroma at the start with some light citrus and caramel underneath. Big and juicy hoppy flavor at the start with a lovely grapefruit and citrus counterbalance. Finishes sweet and hoppy with a very light and dry aftertaste.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2014 Pours from the can into my American Pint glass with a reddish brown hue, darker than most IPAs, certainly it is in the Midwest school of color. The head is foamy and rises to the rim of the glass, it is slightly off-white and leaves bubbly lacing. 

Having brewed my own DIPA today using a pound of hops, I know the fresh hop scents and this brew is bursting with them. The nose is full of concentrated citrusy, spicy hop scent. There is some malt sweetness but only enough to be considered just enough. This is one of the hoppiest smelling brews I have come across.

The hops roll right onto your tastebuds with furious intensity, I dont know if it is because of the can or what but the hops in this one seem really fresh. The malt is there in the taste providing the backbone needed for a solid IPA. 

The Midwestern IPAs are some of the best out there, and this one is the best out of the bunch.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 11-25-2009 23:15:14

Received in trade from Prototypic, thanks for the opportunity.

Pours a crystal clear red/orange amber color with a big fluffy off white head that sticks itself to everything. The aroma, well its hoppy, I could smell grapefruit and pine from the can as I was pouring, yum! Sticking the nose a little clser reveals some grassy notes, faint hint of caramel and maybe some grren apple. Taste reveals a resinous, grapefruity pine taste with an almost abrupt dry finish. Lots of resin and some malt sweetness with a smooth bitter aftertaste. Medium body, Creamy/oily mouthfeel with ample carbonation. Wow thats a great hop bomb, and dangerously drinkable!

De lata. Hazy orange colour, beige head, rather small. 
Fruity sweet hoppy pine aroma. Good mouthfeel. Fruity hoppy sweet piney pleasant bitter flavour.

Ruby amber pour that filled my glass way to the top.  Thanks Dak, for the beautiful beer.  Nose is pungent hops and hints of farmhouse funk/leather.  Taste is same.  Big sweet and slightly "off" flavor.  Lovely mix of togetherness malt and hops with "out there" character.  Not a beer for the masses, I dont think.  Floral and strong.

Can shared by hallinghansen, thanks buddy. 
It pours hazy amber with a off white head. 
The aroma is simcoe hops, caramel, peach, passion fruit and a hint of tee. 
Flavour is bitter and citric with peach, mango, passion fruit and caramel notes. Finishes bitter.

Smell sticky and fruity. Pours an awesome deep red with a glorious head. Taste is perfectly balanced. The right amount of bitterness and the perfect amount of hop flavor to finish it up. Outstanding beer. Every time I drink one (or 5) I am constantly impressed with how tasty this brew is.

Poured into a snifter. Furious pours a really murky burnt sienna color with a nice thick frothy off-white head. Outstanding head retention, which leads to good lacing. Wonderful sweet citrus aromas with a hint of spruce needles. High alpha hops, I am thinking Centennial, control the palate with bitter citrus flavors with some evergreen tones. The sweet malts balance out the bitterness perfectly. Mild carbonation with a smooth and clean backbone. Very complex palate. Nice and crisp with a dry finish. Very nice drinking IPA. I can see why Surly is becoming a big name in the craft beer market.

Can from CLevar.  Thanks man.  Deep amber pour with a good sized khaki head with some decent staying power.  The aroma is mostly a combonation of citrusy hops and toasted caramel malts.  Perhaps an herbal tea note slips in there but its a pretty straight forward scent.  The flavor follows.  This has a sweet, and fairly substantial, caramel malty backbone that counters the citrusy hop bitterness.  I keep thinking pine too but its trumped by tropical fruit.   It drys out a bit in the finish with some good lingering bitterness.  Quite a bit of flavor for 6%.  If youre looking for a balanced IPA, without sacraficing flavor, look no further.  Personally, I still do prefer some of the dryer west coast versions but this is a tasty, and very drinkable (if you like hops) IPA from Surly.

Can thanks to Tharreld. Pours a darker amber color with a tan head. 
Aromas of grapefruit, citrus, touch of sweetness and hops. Flavor is dry of the bat with citrus flavors and some peach with slight sweetness. Nice bitter finish.

Poured into a pint glass. Big thanks to jkblodge for this extra.

4.0 A: Clear orange amber color. Two fingers of frothy, yet dense head that retains exceptionally well. Super sticky and leaves tons of lacing.

4.5 S: Lots of citrusy and piney hops and lots of sweet malts too. Grapefruit and orange citrus with resiny pine. Though the hops run the show, the malts give strong aroma too. Lots of caramel sweetness.

4.0 T: Drier than I expected, yet still not super bitter. Hop flavor centers around resiny and piney hops with grapefruit in the background. Malts arent as complex as in the nose and lend a soft sweetness with a touch of toastiness. Still, this is very tasty.

3.5 M: Light body. Reasonably creamy and super smooth. I know a lot of people like a low FSG with their IPAs, but I like thicker, maltier bodies on mine.

4.0 D: Great aroma and taste, but mouthfeel could use some reinforcement. That said, Id never turn one of these down. A well crafted beer, but could be hoppier.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 12-23-2009 02:38:52

Can, enjoyed while I entered the 22 ratings from the last two tastings I attended.  One of the most balanced and easy drinking IPAs ive ever had.  The citrus, bitter, flower, and hops are balanced.  bitter finish to boot. I wish I could buy this here.
Can from rgtravers. Hazy peach body with a large offwhite head. Aroma issimcoe, peach, fruit and citrus. Flavor is hops, peach, fruit, pine and caramel. Soft carbonation.

Canned. Amber coloured. Murky. Small beige head. aroma of sweetness, herbs, light flowers, light caramel, light pine. flavour of pine, caramel, flowers, herbs. Medium to full bodied. dry grapy bitterness in the end.

Can provided by hallinghansen. Thanks a bunch! Pours hazy amber with a thick creamy off white head. The aroma is passion fruit, citrus, grape fruit, caramel, mango and light grape fruit. The flavour is quite citric with lots of fruity notes as mango, passion fruit and peach. Long citric finish. Great!

500ml can thanks to tbadiuk.
Appearance : Clear ruby red with a small head.

Aroma : Great leafy hops. Nice passion fruits. 

Taste :  Nice fresh and leafy hops with light caramel. A bit oily and sticky. Finish leafy with notes of passion fruits. Sharp bitterness. Dry finish.

Overall : Very soft carbonation but still a bit fizzy. Right on spot for the beer I think. Very nice stuff. Great presence of caramel (not too much). Very drinkable. Lots of hops. Awesome beer.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2011 Pours a hazy orange amber color, with two fingers of frothy head and a huge amount of lacing. Smells of pine hops, grapefruit, and bready caramel malts. Taste builds on these three main elements, with a mostly bitter finish and some lingering citrus. Moderate carbonation and medium body; very enjoyable and I would love to have another.
Fabulous brew.  Aroma is of strong hops and citrus.  Appearance was an orangish amber with a frothy head.  Taste was fairly medium all around, very nice amount of hops.  Very nice, drinkable IPA.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2011 Can (thanks to Beerlando) [first rating of 2011]...  Poured an amber/golden/orange with a thick beige head.  Lots of hops on the nose, citrus, pine.  Incredibly balanced and clean.  Lots of citrus, passionfruit, wood and pine notes.  Malts were subtle but just enough to give a good body.  This was like hop nectar.

This is as near perfection as they come.  I want to bathe in this.  Beautiful amber pour with a medium head.  Thick lacing.  The bitterness hits you in the head and begs you to drink more.  How could this have come out of a can!

A long time coming on this one. Thanks to Syview! Beautiful Ruby colour. Lovely Piney/Citrus Nose. Good balance. Not overly bitter but very very drinkable. Citrus/lemon finish. I really enjoyed this on my trip back to Los Angeles on the Surfliner. Could drink a four pack of this and be a very happy man!

Can thanks to my friend Aaron in MN.  Pours reddish amber with a creamy, sticky off white head.  Nose is fruity hops some light biscuity malts, citrus, oranges, sweet floral notes and resinous hops.  Taste is sweet with medium heavy bitterness that does linger some.  Creamy smooth mouthfeel.  Overall not really and IPA but really flavorful with malts, not caramel, and loads of amarillo smelling hops.  Really a great beer.  How does this style get a whole lot better?

Can to glass.  A real IPA for those of us who like hops.  Nice looking beer, clear copper with caramel and red highlights.  Nice head and retention.  Great aroma of citrus, some pine, just a hint of sweet caramel.  Taste is much the same, with lingering bitterness balanced out by some nice sweet malt notes.  Very nice on the palate.  A great drinking beer.  Glad I live in Minnesota!

16oz can from Zipps Liquors.  Pours a crystal clear amber with a tan head and nice lacing.  Aroma is very grapefruit.   Medium on the palate with light carbonation.  Flavor is a nice balance of malt and citrus hops.  This is a beer that I wish had broader distribution.  You are so lucky Minnesota.

another can courtesy of tyto. i dont know. this sint bad, but it has never really impressed me either. the body is  bit thin for me. still tasty, and nicely hopped. maybe i am just to used to iipas at this point.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 On tap at the Bavarian Lodge in Lisle, IL a few months back.

A: Slightly-hazy darkish orange with a good head and some lacing.

S: Citrus and pine hops with a good sweet malt underbelly. 

T: Good caramel sweet malt underneath with some sweet fruits mixed in. On top of that are some clear citrus and pine hops.

M: Medium body with good carbonation and not too much alcohol in the flavor.

D: Exceptional. Probably the best American IPA that I have ever had.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 05-01-2009

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2011 Murky orange pour with a nice thick pillowy white head.  Excellent juicy citrus and pine notes jumped from the glass, big time hop aroma.  Citrusy hop flavors were well dispersed throughout this one, decent caramel malt back-end to balance it nicely.  Mouthfeel was medium bodied, perfect carbonation, dry big bitter finish yet very smooth.  Overall this was well done.  The name fits the brew nicely, its a big hoppy bitter IPA.  Damn good at that.  First from Surly.  Thanks to DalzAle for sending me another to re-try.

16 oz. can from Skyview. A hazy reddish-brown beer with a 1" head that looks good. The aroma is  very nice. Its piney and has a spiciness that comes off as cinnamon kind of like spicy cinnamon gum. If you like aromas from IPAs then youll like this. The taste has a nice crisp hop bite. This is a good IPA. Again more piney flavors and has a spice to it that I guess comes from the hops but is very interesting. Now only if I can convince Surly to come to TX then I will stop emailing them about it 5 times a day.

Appearance: deep garnets, ambers, and rubies. Generous head leaves clumps of lace on sides of glass and a concaved head much like a donut, but better. Swirls with more lace and more puff.

Nose: fresh whole green hop cones abound with sticky hops resins. Hint of pine but overall green hops dominate. Pine needles and sense of dry pine forests in the back. No citrus except for some tangerine skin. Dry underneath with melba.

Palate: surprisingly light and smooth with a clean presence of flavors across my palate. Immediate presence of green hop cones which increase and grow with each quaff. Bitterness of resins and dried leaves in the back. Crunchy and toasty underneath with a hint of toffee bar sweetness. Palate slowly dries. Sticky lips with hop resins and toffee. Not a big body which really lets the flavors shine through. Sessionable and flavorful. Hop resins in my breath.

Final Thoughts: another grand hitter in the scheme of craft beer in cans, Surly can make my day any time. Seriously. Please. May I have another?

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2013 Fruity, piny, and hoppy aroma. Citrus, pine, and hop flavors envelop your mouth and finish with a piny hop bitterness. Well carbonated with a velvety resinous quality make this a very good beer for pairing with food.

Can. Pours Amber/slightly red with medium off white head. Aroma is plenty hoppy with big floral and citrus notes. Flavor is grapefruit hops with a nice malty finish to balance the beer. Definitely try this one if youre a hop head!

On tap in Minneapolis.  Comes a clear orange amber with a nice biege head.  Aroma of floral and piney hops with some citrus and malt.  Lots of hops in the taste, also citrus, caramel and malt.  Very nice IPA.
Great staple brew from Surly. Aroma is really nice. The flavor is definitely unique. This is an easy to drink IPA, not as hoppy as most, but good good beer.

This beer is a definite staple and theres always at least a 4 pack in my mini fridge.
If you like hops and bitterness this is the beer for you.

Can courtesy bu11zeye. He threw this can in my bag before I left. Shit I can smell the hops the second I crack the lid. Pours a hazy reddish orange color. Flavor is less hop aggressive than the nose. More of an earthy flavor with some hoppy bitterness. Finishes dry and hoppy.

Can from bu11zeye.  Copper pour with a big white head.  Aroma is awesome fruit hops, caramel, and some more great, juicy hops.  Taste is caramel, dry, bitter, bread, and hops.  Hops linger on the finish in a great way.
There is a lot of flavor going on. Very prominent hops but balanced well with malty sweetness. Well done. Serving: Tap

Can and draft. This is probably one of my best beers to have out in the cites when I cant find anytihng else that I want. Pours a really nice orange amber color with a nice white head. Excellent aroma of both citrus rind and slight pine notes in the nose along with some sweet malt backbone. Medium mouthfeel and a bit chewy. Sweet malt flavors up fornt wuickly give way to vibrant hops taste. Citrus rind, grapefruit, and pine all in one. Really well balanced. Just an excellent flagship beer.

From a can (of course).  Deep amber pour with nice tan head.  Floral and citrus hop aroma.  Even some pine in there.  Taste is hop (of course), but surprisingly balanced with caramel malt.  citrus/pine on the flavor.  Very bitter (in a good way).  One of the best IPAs out there...

Surly Furious is a very clear copper ale with a dense khaki head that has outstanding retention and lacing.  It has a huge, fresh hop aroma with pine and grapefruit bust bursting out.  It smells juicy and fruity.  Its pretty full bodied and super smooth.  The hops leave the tongue a touch singed.  Oh, this is nice and bitter and hoppy.  Theres a nice full hop flavor here.  Its along the lines of Nugget Nectar or Hop Stoopid, but less sweet and more piney.  Its perfectly balanced.  After almost 800 beer ratings, this is the best rating yet.  This IPA is perfect in almost every way.  The can keeps it fresh.  I wish I could buy this in Upstate New York!
Poured from a can. Deep amber color and lots of floral piney aroma. Extremely balanced and has some alcohol in the back. GREAT STUFF!

I wish this beer was around when I used to live in Minneapolis. Amazing hop heavy beer with great fresh hopped up aroma and a hop infused carmel/toffee flavor. Great job Surly. I strongly recommend this one to any IPA lovers out there."

Received this in the mail today, courtesy of Nate. Pours a nice cloudy, orange hue.  Nice hoppy profile and is balanced very well.  This is one of the better IPAs Ive had in a while and certainly lived up to its hype.

Thanks to daknole for giving me this beer as an extra!

Aroma:Tons of fresh smelling hops in the nose. The hops smell mildly like grapefruit.

Appearance:Deep amber in color. Nice off-white head with big bubbles.

Taste:This beer has TONS of hops on the foretaste. The hops are grapefruit, apricot, and peach. The malt on this one shines through as well with its nuttyness on the aftertaste.

Palate:The body is light to medium. Theres some hop astringency due to the massive hop bomb.

Overall:I really enjoyed this beer, lots of complexity, delicious fruity hop flavor, easy to drink.
Thanks savvy1982. Pours dark orange, The aroma has grapefruit, lemon and caramel. the flavor is malty, citric and very bitter. Not bad, but it just seems a little dull.

A clear, amber-red pour with tan head.  The aroma has some citrus and vague caramel, but is really dominated by pine.  The taste begins bittersweet and finishes just plain bitter.  The medium body has a slick texture and average carbonation.

(can, courtesy of Andrew; sampled 4/10/10). Clear dark copper color. Small off white head. Moderate citrus/pine aroma, with light earthiness. Flavor of the same, with light sweet maltiness. Long duration. Light bitter finish. Thin/slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

Sampled on 8/13/2010. This IPA pours a slightly hazy amber brown color from a 16oz can. Medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is citrusy, caramel and fruity. A medium bodied IPA. The malts are caramel, peaty, fruity and sweet. The hops are citrusy and herbal. Nice balance. Good carbonation. More in the English (or maybe Scottish?) style of an IPA. A mild hoppiness tends to linger on the palate. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

16oz can,  Pretty nice appearance, a deep orange-brown body with a large, foamy, beige head.  A really nice IPA, with a mellow enough malt body to really let the hop flavor shine.  Very hoppy finish, coats the mouth in a bitter stickiness.  Slight English feel to it, but the bigger ABV and mega-hop taste is all US.  Some pleasant dark malt tones in there as well.  Surprisingly soft and restrained despite the soapy, piny tones.  Well done.

Picked up this pint sized can at Discount Liquors, in Milwaukee. This was $4.99 for one pint, so
this quite expensive, but I dont think Ill have the opportunity to try this again. This beer has a nice
brown color with a wispy head. This beer is dark for an IPA, but it looks great. The beer has a very pungent hop 
aroma. Smells very resinous. Has a lovely and fresh hop aroma. Not as bitter as thought it would be, but this
still has a wonderful flavor. Nice citrus hop at first, and then it gets into a deep pine flavor. This beer leaves
quite the bitterness on the tongue. As my brother noted while drinking this, its a bit on the thin side. Its not
watery, but it doesnt have the "nicest" texture, as some world class IPAs seem to have. Overall, this beer provides
a decent amount of bitterness, but it is lacking in some areas, such as texture to carry along those bitter 
qualities.

HOP BOMB! draft at Sheffields. reddish with a nice tan head. slight malt sweetness initially, then the hops kick in and dominate. hop bitterness, aroma, and flavor enormous throughout. Resinous and chewy.


Surly Furious Simcoe dry-hopped on cask at The Map Room - I prefer stouts on cask, IPAs lose their punch on cask. deep reddish color, wispy head. I would have loved to have had the dry hopped version NOT on cask. It just softens the beer too much.
On tap.  Pour is amber with a small white head.  Aroma is sweet with citrus notes and pine.  Flavor is a nice balance of sweet malt and aggressive bitter hops.  Really good if you like strong hops.

Pour is dark amber, with a thin off white head.  Aroma is mandarin orange, piney resin, mouthfeel is thin but appropriate, really nice drinking.  
Flavor is wonderful herbacious hops with a light malt backbone.  Damn good drinking.

Clear orange amber with a thin white head. Lots of piney herbal notes in the nose with huge mandarin orange and tropical nectar fruit notes. The flavor holds lots of grassy herbal evergreen notes with more citrus oriented nectar incarnations and some slight perfume notes. The mouthfeel is on the thin side, but coupled with the pillowy light effervescence, I think it really works here.

Dark copper pour with a small head. Aroma holds mandarin orange, pine, ruby red grapefruit, and a touch of floral hops. Flavor is fresh and lively, with further evergreen notes, citrus, and some additional grass and herbal components. A bit thin, but thats expected for a regular IPA. Drinks well- damn good stuff.

Can courtesy of Wavers1. Really nice IPA.  The malts are strongest on the nose with hints of honey and grassy hops.  Color is a dark amber with robust white head an good lacing.  Taste is very hoppy (the 100 IBUs come through)  grass and herbal hints with a nice malt backbone.  Palate is nice and creamy.

Can - courtesy of tytoanderso! Dark copper pour. Medium beige head leaves spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma is slightly spicy hops, pine and citrus oils. Soft malt as well. Taste is big hops - mainly spicy and citrus notes. Soft pine, light caramel and malt notes. Body is medium and resinous with a creamy carbonation. Ends with more citrusy hops and spicy hops, light caramel, malt notes and orange peel.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2011 Tried again from the can. Big pine, resin, wood, light caramel and flowers. Excellent and very well put-together. Also beautiful. Can on RBSG bus. From Guyinchicago, I think. Deep amber with a nice thin lacy head. Nice aroma, big, big fruit, dry, simcoe, nice citrus and grass. Smooth body, not a lot of carbonation. Not too much caramel either. Just a bit. Malt is understated, hops take over. Very smooth bitterness, nice citrusy grass. Great stuff.  8/4/8/3/15

Pint sized can courtesy of Greg.  Pours a clear dark amber with a medium sized cream colored head.  Aroma of faint pine, malt, citrus and hops.  Taste of light pine, faint citrus, malt and hops.  I doubt this is a fresh can and Id would love to try a fresh one in the future.

Can, thanks to Skyview. Pours clear deep orange/amber, thin but persistent off-white head. Great lacing. Nose is sweet malt, big spicy hops, very PNW, overtop of sweet cereal malt. Balanced, flavours are also well-balanced, citrus and pine play off sweet malt. Nice.

pours clear dark amber. Slight head. Great aroma holy and bold with a slight caramel aroma. Flavour is strong hopy and bitter with a very malt forward. It is a nice IPA but very Malty. Well balanced but not blowing my mind.
Smells quite strongly of hops, thats all. Not much head or lacing, quite clear, reddish brown sort of. Nice bitter taste, lasts a long time on your tounge. Not bad, but its all hops and thats it.
Can. Pours golden/amber with a big white head and lots of lacing. Aroma of hops hits you immediately. Big pine taste with a nice malt backbone. Really nice IPA.

16 ounce can courtesy of tarheels86, thanks you sir.  Bright amber color, huge fluffy of white head, massive lacing.  Aroma of pine tar and citrus.  Taste is floral hops, citrus, pine.  Not too bitter, well balanced.  Tasty.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2010 My 100th IPA rating. Can courtesy of Santa!. Pours a clear deepish amber to red with a massively rocky head, massive lacing of God. Piney, citrus, sappy, perfumey hops, toffee, dirty, iron rich earth. Taste is not too bitter- lots of nice Scotch malt, fairly sweet and creamy with piney, herbal hops. Excellent palate. These cans dont last for more than a few seconds because the beer is so damn good.
Hoppy and proud of it. Great red-ish color and fiery aroma. A great local brew with a high re-drink value that keeps bringing me back. I really like the balance of this beer

Thanks to the kindness of Tim @ Pinocchios
Poured a reddish, orangish amber with a smallish head which dissapted into a coating of bubbles. Nose was grapefruit and pine, some caramel malt and some flowery aroma as well. Taste was initally malts - esp. caramel and then the hops kick in - piney citrus (grapefruit and pineapple) and some floral, perfumy and pleasantly bitter back end. This is a hop-bomb for sure, but not one of those that render you unable to taste anything else for days. It IS enough to maybe limit the number of these at a sitting. Mouthfeel is medium with some prickly feeling and a nice, crisp finish. Carbonation seems light as well. all-in-all a great offering and one I wish I had more access to.

From trade via KButler1.  Amazing aroma of earhty and piney hops.  A whiff of caramel.  Attractive red/orange color, translucent, large white head.  The flavor is hops upfront again, piney, earthy, then some caramel sweetness (rather faint, though).  The finish is a steady citrus bittering, but not nearly as intense as I had come to expect from the aroma and flavor.  medium to medium/thick in body.  Very, very good.  Thanks, Kevin.

Can  Pours a cloudy dark amber with a froathy tan head.  The head lasts well and laces nicely.  Has a good hoppy aroma of citrus, grapefruit, pine, and a touch of malts.  Has a good carbonation.  The flavor is great.  Hoppy but not too much.  Good sweet citrus.  Very crisp and refreshing.  Has a medium body.  The texture is a touch dry with an oily side.  A real good finish with a pleasing lingering aftertaste.  A very easy drinking hearty IPA.  Waited a while to get one of these and well worth it.

16oz. Can (from trade with phaleslu):  Pungent aroma of hops, grass, pine, citrus, light malt, and hints of grapefruit and pineapple.  Poured amber in color with a medium-sized, creamy, dense, rocky, tan head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Lightly sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is medium to heavily bitter, and lightly sweet.  Tastes of hops, pine, sweet malt, grass, slight caramel, and slight Earth.  Medium body.  Average texture, is a tad oily.  Average carbonation.  Hops, slight malt, pine, slight resin, and grass finish.

Pours a dark orange/amber with a light brown head. Aroma is fantastic with grapefruit and floral hops. I detect some pine in there as well. Watching game 2 of the college world series finals while drinking this. South Carolina vs. UCLA with USC up 1-0 in the series. I write this because the beer is good enough that I want to note where I was and what I was doing when I had it for the first time. I believe you experience beer, and this is all part of it. Up in Minneapolis on business.  Deliciously hopped with good grapefruit flavor. I also get what seems to be a mix of lemon, orange, and grapefruit citrus rinds as if the skins were grated into the batch. The hops really showcase the beer, but are not overpowering so the flavors really shine through. Definitely has a floral/pine flavor in the background. The body is well balanced, and the beer goes down very smooth. All around strong beer.

Thanks to Tharreld for the can!! It pours a dark amber color with a dense orangy head. It has a really great aroma of spruce, caramel, grapefruit, pineapple and mango. The flavor is very sweet and malty with lots of tropical fruit, caramel, and a hint of brown sugar. The grapefruity hops come through strong in the finish with hints of pine and spruce. This is definitely a sweeter maltier IPA with a smoother body (lower carbonation) than most others. Very tasty stuff.

Huge, healthy head cratering over gold/copper beer.  Citrus, pine, and heavy malt component in the aroma and taste.  Perhaps my can was dated because the hop presence seemed a bit faded.  Overall, quite good but Id like to try this fresh just to confirm its quality.

I moved to Minneapolis today, and this was first on my list of Twin Cities beers to try.  I bought a 4-pack of cans, but when I got home I realized I didnt have any glassware to pour the can into, so Im drinking this out of a washed out iced coffee cup.

Pours the color of my hair in the sunshine... sorry, pours a beautiful reddish brown ;) with a thick foamy head that dissolves slowly, leaving lots of lacing all over the plastic coffee cup.  The aroma is like sticking your nose into a hop garden, mostly herbal, pine, etc. with just a hint of good potting soil.  Despite the strong hop smell, the flavor isnt too bitter.  Mostly sweet, with a little kick in the back.  Thick mouthfeel, with a refreshing menthol burst right at the end.  This is a really enjoyable beer all around, and Im so excited to now live where I can buy it just about anywhere.

canned, via trade with ketchepillar, orange amber color with good off white foam, aroma has some floral notes along with good citrus and pine, flavor has a balance of malt and grapefruit, very smooth finish although slightly metallic

Appearance: Iced tea with a 2 finger frothy beige crown that has some retention and a good amount of lacing.

Smell: Loads of grapefruit, a nice caramel toffee malt, and some pine.

Taste: Caramel malt is present through the entire sip. Grapefruit not so dominant in the flavor profile. Some bitterness and notes of toffee.

Mouthfeel: Thin and well carbonated but still a touch chewy....kinda strange but not bad.

Drinkability: Im not digging the flavor profile very much but the mouthfeel really makes this one drinkable.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 06-26-2009

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this beer that has been on my wants for a long time.

The beer pours an orange color with an off-white head. The aroma is heavy on the hops with resin and citrus. The flavor is more of the same with a great mix of resiny hops and citrus hops. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A great beer, but it is one that I dont have much to say about. This is one I definitely recommend and it lived up to the hype.

I rolled my eyes initially when the guy at the liquor store suggested trying Surly; Minnesota? A great beer brewed in Minnesota (I live in Minnesota FYI)? Turns out there are several great beers that are brewed in Minnesota- Minneapolis Town Hall Brewery, Masala Mama IPA.

Pours Amber with medium white head. Huge lacing. Aroma of citrus and floral hops, grass, light sugar.  Flavor is similar, with a heavier malt backbone. Lightly citric and floral.  Finishes bitter and resinous.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2011 On tap at Monks in Sioux Falls-  Deep orange color with medium white head.  Citrus and hops to the nose.  Taste is similar, grapefruit came to mind several times.  Very citrusy without being fruity.  Fresh hops always in the background.  Smooth, medium bodied, medium carbonation.  What a treat.

500 ml can. Hazy deep reddish copper. Medium-sized white fine-laced head. Nutty and toffee-like malty aroma with a bold floral and grassy hops aroma. Rich malts and lots of caramel and toffe. Notes of bread and biscuits. Apricots and bitter hops. Nice balance between sweetish caramelly flavours and bold hops.
Amber pour with an off-white head. Super hop aroma of citrus. Papow. Taste is spicy, bitter hops that balance with a tastty malt backbone. Creamy smooth. I want more. Nice lacing

On tap at Jake Melnicks in dowtown Chicago. Im pretty sure this was just the normal Furious and not the tea-bagged version. Amber color, darker than what I would expect from an IPA. Thick, fluffy head retains well and produces some nice lacing. Citrus and grapefruit in the aroma.Very citrusy taste with some grass notes. Very smooth -- the beer goes down so easy, yet its very full flavored. Nice bitter hoppy finish that leaves you wanting more.  I could drink several of these as a session beer. Its clean an refreshing. Would also go great with a fish or chicken dinner.

Firkin of tea-bagged at DLD 10.  Iced tea colored pour with no head.  Intensely floral with notes of earl grey, some slight malt sweetness, loads of tasty juicy grapefruit and citrus in the middle and a long bitter finish with evergreen and juniper.  Creamy medium body with low carbonation.

Draft at Sheffields in Chicago.  Ive waited a long time for this beer and I was not disappointed.  A malty, citrusy, balanced ipa with hops from beginning to end.  Extremely fresh!  A fantastic ipa.

Thanks to delriumfest for this one!

A- Body is a translucent dark amber/ ruby red hue. Pours with a nice 2 finger creamy white head which slowly subsides to 1/2 finger and has perfect retention from there. Leaves lots of lacing all the way down the glass. Body is uniform in color/conistency.

S-Caramel, toffee, and spicy hops come to the nose first and at the end is a big dose of citrus. Smell falls on the sweet/spicy end of the IPA spectrum.

T-The initial flavor is quite subdued, a hint of earthy hops comes through with an even smaller dose of pine mixed in. The finish is where this beer gets complex. Caramel malt sweetness comes though in a big way in an attempt to balance the assault of piny hops, citrus hop flavor, citrus hop resiny bitterness, and a spicy hop accent. What lingers is a medium to high residual hop bitterness and a hint of spicy hops.

P- Wow. Very well done. Medium tingly carbonation and a smooth oily body.

O- This reminds me of a good red ale rather than an IPA. The flavor is smooth and balanced and this is certainly not a hop bomb-though the hop bitterness is there. My first Surly brew, and I have been waiting to try Surly for quite a long time now. Well done overall and something I would trade for again

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 12-24-2008 02:00:44

Can.  Pours clear amber to dark copper with a medium, creamy off-white head, fair retention.  Aroma is huge citrus, floral, pine hops with medium, caramel sweet malt, light fruity esters, and light alcohol.  Flavor is medium sweet malt, huge hop flavor (pine, citrus, floral) with light alcohol and a dry finish.  Medium body, moderate carbonation.

Can from a trade with phaleslu. Pours hazy copper color with cream colored head. Aromas of grapefruit and caramel. Bitter grapefruit flavor with sweet biscuity malts. Medium body with average carbonation and a resinous mouthfeel. Thanks Peter.

On tap @ the Bavarian Lodge. Pours a clear copper-amber with a medium white head that leaves tons of lacing. The aroma is very fresh hops, with citrus, orange, floral, and grassy notes. The flavor is similar, with a nice malty backbone, but very hop forward. Very tasty, mostly balanced, and bitter as hell.

Consumed on a snowy winters day in Minnesota while on an unexpected layover with the family. Craving craft beer and indian food so dragged brother-in-law to Tandoor restaurant up the street from the Embassy Suites. Pours crimson-amber with little head. Smells of candied fruit, red licorice, caramel, orange oils from citrusy hops. Brilliant fruity, hoppy, warming spice, creme caramel with a balanced finish. Body is resinous, full, soft effervescent mouthfeel. This IPA was a divine paring with samosas.

Completely caught off guard with this beer. Personally the can thing is getting redundant, but this was actually a solid beer that I would love to come back too, sorry fat tire but you ruined me on cans, but you also ruined a lot of things for me. Big citrusy hops, well balanced and I can drink these at a Raiders game without the worry of getting hurt when the parking lot gets rowdy and this comes my way in the air. Big fan, now I need to get some more.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2010 My first beer in over 2 weeks.  Thanks to Mr. Brendo for the can.  Pours a deep chestnut with a thin but solid layer of tan head atop.  nose has profound elements of sweet pine, grilled citrus, ribbon candy, and a background peatiness.  Flavors are a bit biscuity though...lots of caramelly malt under the somewhat faceless hop character.  Certainly has more of a thick biscuity boldness than the vibrant fresh hop refreshness that Im used to in west coast IPAs.  Its clean though, the flavors mend together sufficiently, but its almost got an arrogant bastard like-feel to it where I wouldnt ever really seek it out again.

(16oz can via trade with StFun) rich clear orange, huge fluffy light tan head and excellent lacing. Nose of juicy grapefruit, biscuit, and yeast. Taste of subdued grapefruit ad orange oils, biscuit and caramel. I think this may be slightly aged. Oily mouthfeel. If fresh this is probably amazing.

This is a great beer. It smells great when you pour it. The bitter flavor is what makes it taste so great to me. It leaves a good after taste in your mouth. By far my favorite beer I have ever tried so far. Keep in mind I have many many beers yet to try.

This beer is absolutely bursting with hoppy aroma and flavor. The moment you open the can it gives off such a resiny citrus hop aroma. It pours into the glass a dark amber to copper color with a nice creamy head that appears to lose nothing from the brewers beloved canning method. The taste, oh the taste! This packs as much flavor as many of the DIPAs that I have tried. It is so citrusy, piney, and bitter.

Arrived from the tap a clear, deep amber color with a tall and creamy off-white head. Aroma has a strong pine hops presence, modest amount of malt toasted notes and finishes with some mild lemon citrus and spicy hops notes without a hint of sweetness in it. Flavor has a nice maris otter type of toasted malt presence under a strong piney and leafy hoppy bitterness that really works well with strong malt character. Bitterness really has a strong staying power well after the beer has been downed. Beer has a moderate density for the body with a very crisp texture to it. Overall a fantastic brew. The dry hopped aroma matched the prevalent bitter bite found in the flavor perfectly. Really enjoyable brew!

Great pour from a 16oz can into a pint glass.  Cooler aroma comes off as hoppy with a grapefruit and toffee smell.  The first taste comes off as hoppy and quickly transitions to grapefruit and toffee flavors as the beer warms the flavor becomes fruitier.  I do not feel overpowered by the hops but they slightly overpower the malt, just barely.  The mouthfeel starts off smooth and silky as it warms there is more CO2 bite and more aromatics come off the flavors seem to brighten up and really combine better and balance more.

16 oz. can to pint glass. Pour is deep amber with a frothy head that slowly dissapears to film on top. Aroma is hop, hops, and more hops with citrus floral scents as well. Taste is strong grapfruit with honey and florals with a dry finish. Palate is medium feel with a chaulky finish. I regret rating this now considering that I have been drinking this for the last four years, but what do you do? This is right up there with two hearted for me, awesome IPA!

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2014 Tasted In Can 3/10- Dark body for an IPA, with a malty mouthfeel full of caramel and oats, which lead into domimant hop presence through the medium length. Theres tasty malt here, but this is basically liquid hops, and well-balanced. 
Tasted on Draft 1/14- Rich caramel and toffee malt are complemented by a strong grapefruit note and a massive, fresh piney hope presence. Citrus comes through heavily on the finish. This is complexly layered with a blast of hops lingering to add balannce. Upgrade rating by 0.1.

Pours orange/red into the glass with a white head.  Aroma is amazingly resinous and piny hops.  This beer is over the top hopped.  Unfortunately there is virtually no malt backbone to this beer which leaves this tasting more like hop tea.  Very thin mouthfeel makes this beer unimpressive.

Aroma - A fruit cup. No really, not grapefruit, not piney resin, a fruit cup. Some caramel as well but a refreshing nose to draw you into the depths of this offering. 

Appearance - Poured into a pilsner glass from a 16oz metal can. Nice markings on the can to include "99 IBUs". Should be interesting. Popping the can doesnt release any noteworthy carbonation sounds. The pout produces a mild one finger head. The resolution is nice, with good lacing on the sides of the glass (left enough headroom on the pour). Color is a clear orange-amber with ample carbonation feeding the remaining head. 

Taste - First the hops, have to make mention of the obvious. Yes, they are present here in ample quantities, but the "force" behind them is well-balanced with a very present malty backbone. There is depth to this hop presence, more so than Ive tasted in many DIPAs which seem to be more focused on "quantity". Yes, this is an IPA, a very tasty IPA. The expected finishing hop bite was very blunted (which is very much welcomed to this malt lover). Enjoyable. 

Palate - The body is very dense for this offering. Lots to chew on here. There is a creaminess here that is outstanding. Nice "layering" on the tongue while at the same time a tongue-cleansing finish. 

Overall - Perhaps my can had some age on it, or Ive been trying to expand into DIPAs recently that I very much enjoyed this IPA. Top 10 IPA? Yes, well-ranked from my limited experience/perspective. I liked it better than Sculpin. I need more of this.
Great citrus aroma, beautiful amber/red color. Tastes like citrus resiny hop juice with a nice backbone of malt.  I Love this beer.

Tasted on draft at Goose Island Clybourn.  Pours a clear amber orange with a laced white head.  There is a very hoppy grapefruit aroma with a little bit of malt.  The flavors are super hoppy grapefruit peel and juniper.  The body and carbonation are medium, and the finish is long and bitter.

Poured out of a can into a goblet. Copper clear color, a little darker than most IPAs that I am used to. Sweet malty aroma with a hint of piney hops. Very malty taste with a nice bitter finish. A lil maltier than I generally like my IPAs. Decent IPA would trade for this again.
citric grapefruit on nosing, the hops are massive, but somehow the beer is balanced. very complex on palate with great resiny/piny finish. so much for the shitty beer in can thinking. awesome beer

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2010 tasting on 3/6/10... very deep orange pour ... huge deep citrus hop notes on the nose with some earthy and grassy feeling to it... some dark fruit linger in over the body and some light banana notes as well.  very full creamy smooth mouthfeel... a great IPA ... definitely not your average IPA in the least bit.

Draft at the Brat cabin.  Piney aroma that is almost resin(resinous)  Dark red/amber almost brown color with a small rim of head.  Fermented fairly dry in the finish.  Centennial hops are ver prominent nos as balanced as a Bells 2 hearted ale.  Slight belgian lace.  Resin aroma all the way through.

Can.  Poured a clear golden amber with a frothy egg shell.  Lots of pine in the nose, also some earthy grass and grapefruit notes are also present.  Mostly full body with a round mouth feel and decent carbonation.  Medium sweet with notes of grapefruit, floral hops, caramel, and pine.  Finishes medium sweet with a good amount of hop bitterness.

I am biased. I love this beer so much that it is the beer by which I measure all others.   The aroma is a delightful bitter floral grapefruit. Color is beautiful reddish brown. Taste is a fantastic bitter grapefruit that lingers for minutes. Full boddied rich IPA. Just awesome.

Canned, thanks Cletus!  Hazy dark amber, small head. Lychee aroma. Mid-sweet with medium body and vital, rounded mouthfeel. Juicy flavour where gooseberry, lychee and winegums dominates. Grapfruity bitter finish. Very aromatic, very good.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2011 Copper clear with 1 cm foam dissipating to a fine lace.  The initial aroma is WOW! on the nose.  Nice floral and spruce hops. The malt may be a bit overpowered by the heavy bitterness (99 IBU!), but some good caramel comes through. The 6.2 % alcohol is well masked (dangerous with those tall cans!)  The palate was the only disappointment, with some sticky/soapy feeling on the finish.  Nicely made IPA.  I would definitely get it again.
7/6/2011
OK, I found some again and had to improve the rating.  I didnt get the soapy/stickiness this time.  Probably a testament to unpasteurized beer that I have to transport hundreds of miles after buying.  Cant say enough about the outstanding, complex aroma of this beer.

The first beer in a can Ive been excited about since I was 18. Thanks to cvaypai for sending one my way.

A: Clear amber color with a good sized white head.

S: Very floral and piney.

T: Malty and caramelly--somewhat sweeter than Im used to with an IPA, but a good bitter piney finish

M: Very nice level of carbonation, medium body.

D: Quite drinkable. Id definitely have this again.
